questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. A Python script is used to configure a Cisco IOS XE router. The Loopback2 interface currently has a description of Management2 and an IP address/netmask of 10.222.34.22/32. What is the result of executing the script?

choices.C: The interface is removed from the configuration.
choices.D: The interface description is removed from the configuration.
choices.A: The interface description remains the same.
choices.B: The router rejects all commands and the configuration remains the same.

discussion.content: D. The interface description is removed from the configuration. look at PUT it replace everything

Correct Answer is D. PUT replaces everything. If you want to replace only a specific item for a particular item, then use PATCH.
https://medium.com/@9cv9official/what-are-get-post-put-patch-delete-a-walkthrough-with-javascripts-fetch-api-17be31755d28

Selected Answer: D
Just run the given code on my lab, the description is removed !

Selected Answer: D
To mantain the same description we should use PATCH

Selected Answer: D
D is correct, PUT will replace the entire config for that interface so essentially the interface config will be wiped and then re-added based on the "data" given. More happens than just the interface description being removed, but that's the only one of the answers which is correct

Selected Answer: A
In Cisco IOS XE router rest API, it only use PUT to edit the configuration and it will remain the configuration that the PUT request not mention.
D is correct but oh man this is just awful, terrible code.
A. with_items

Answer is A
https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/2.4/playbooks_loops.html

Selected Answer: A
Most definitely A

Selected Answer: A
A
with_items
https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/playbook_guide/playbooks_loops.html#with-items
It seems that A is the correct answer
Answer is C

Selected Answer: C
p1 = ospf_interface('1/1', '100', '1') 
--> The parameter 1/1 is passed to the function ospf_interface(...) as first parameter, so that will be the value of "interface" (see function definition) that will be used in the function

Selected Answer: C
Answer is C
C. ethernet 1/1 is the correct answer

comments.content:
p1 = ospf_interface('1/1', '100', '1')
'1/1' correlates to the parameter 'interface' of the function (ospf_interface) and then '100' to the 'process' (ID) and 'area' to '1'
which means that value 1/1 is invoked as an argument(if I can say so, I'm not a programmer) for the interface parameter.

Ans: 1/1 is the interface
I though so too, but why? Is that because it is the first item on the list?

discussion.content: C. is correct answer

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. Which interface is included in the payload resulting from the script?

discussion.content:
Correct answer B D
Explanation:
A.description is a leaf
B. is correct
C address is defined in iet-ip module
D. is correct
E. Doesn't make too much sense to me.

Source:
https://yangcatalog.org/yang-search/yang_tree/ietf-ip@2018-02-22
https://yangcatalog.org/yang-search/yang_tree/ietf-interfaces@2013-02-06

comments.content: I mean E is wrong, inside the container interface, there is no other container.
D is wrong: inside the container interface, there is no other container.
E is wrong because interface is a list, not a container

choices.E: interface has the YANG data node type of container
choices.C: address is a container defined in the ietf-interfaces module
choices.A: description is a key field defined in the interface list
choices.B: The ethernetCsmacd type is imported from the iana-if-type module
choices.D: ipv4 is a container defined in the ietf-ip module

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. A RESTCONF GET request is sent to a Cisco IOS XE device. The base URL of the request and the response in XML format are shown in the exhibit. What are the two YANG data nodes and modules referenced in the response? (Choose two.)
